items.title: Outdoor trick-or-treating in Sonoma County is safe this Halloween with precautions
items.summary: Families can confidently enjoy outdoor trick-or-treating on Halloween and outdoor Día De los Muertos celebrations this year, provided they take some simple precautions to reduce the risk of spreading COVID-19, Dr. Sundari Mase, Sonoma County’s public health officer, advised Thursday.

items.title: Fall in Love Adoption Special October 13-23, 2021
items.summary: Could a new dog, cat or bunny companion bring you happiness and joy? Fall in love with one of our animals today!

items.title: Weekly Roundup for October 8, 2021
items.summary: This week’s digest provides helpful and important updates on the following: 1) Vaccine mandate for California schools; 2) Flu shot recommendations; 3) Criteria to lift mask mandate; 4) Guidance on testing; 5) COVID-19 community resources & support; 6) Other county news items; 7) Emergency preparedness tips & resources

items.title: Sonoma County campaign delivers 700,000th vaccination
items.summary: Reaching another major milestone in the battle against COVID-19, the campaign to protect Sonoma County residents from the virus delivered its 700,000th dose of vaccine this week.

items.title: Bay Area Health Officers Issue Criteria for Lifting COVID-19 Indoor Masking Requirements
items.summary: As decisions to vaccinate and wear face coverings indoors drive down COVID-19 case rates and hospitalizations, health officers for the nine Bay Area jurisdictions that require face coverings in most indoor public spaces today reached consensus on criteria to lift those health orders.

items.title: Intimate Partner Violence is a Leading Cause of Death in Pregnancy and Postpartum.
items.summary: 1 in 4 Women Experience Intimate Partner Violence in Their Lifetime. Learn about resources for support and prevention including the Family Justice Center, National Domestic Violence Hotline, and the Futures Without Violence Toolkit.

items.title: Sonoma County Health Officer requires flu shots for health care workers, recommends them for public
items.summary: Sonoma County Health Officer Dr. Sundari Mase today issued a health order requiring workers at certain health care and congregate facilities to get vaccinated against influenza.

items.title: Weekly Roundup for October 1, 2021
items.summary: This week’s digest provides helpful and important updates on the following:1) Update on booster shots; 2) New guidance on safely holding public meetings; Latest on vaccines for 5- to 11-year-olds; Update on the status of in-person school; Upcoming COVID-19 vaccine clinics and expanded testing; COVID-19 community resources & support; Other Sonoma County news items; and Emergency preparedness tips & resources.

items.title: Got your Covid Vaccination? You're Not Done Yet-Get your Flu Vaccination too and Prevent a Twindemic.
items.summary: We may see a tough flu season this year as Covid prevention measures are relaxed, and because our immune systems were not challenged by flu last year. Prevent a potential Twindemic by getting vaccinated for flu now.

items.title: Sonoma County rolls out COVID-19 booster shots
items.summary: COVID-19 booster shots are available in Sonoma County for eligible seniors, health care workers, public safety personnel and others who are at increased risk for COVID-19 exposure and transmission because of occupational or institutional setting, and who received the second dose of the two-shot Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine at least six months ago.

items.title: New Research and Educational Opportunities for Maternal Child and Adolescent Health Professionals.
items.summary: Clarifying ACES Screening and Mandated Reporting Requirements. National Partnership for Women on Defining, Creating and Sustaining Optimal Maternal Health. Healthy Outcomes From Positive Experiences. How Gratitude Can Reduce Burnout in Health Care. The Commission on the Status of Women in Sonoma County. STI Clinical Update Webinar.

items.title: Syphilis during pregnancy can cause fetal and infant loss and newborn birth defects and health challenges.
items.summary: Syphilis during pregnancy can cause fetal and infant loss and newborn birth defects and health challenges. Learn more about how untreated syphilis can affect a baby's health and the California Department of Public Health screening recommendations for syphilis.
